overview_of_class: This course will introduce students to some perennial questions in the philosophy of morality. We will be concerned with questions about (1) the nature of morality: For instance, are there universal, objective truths about right and wrong? Or is morality ultimately a subjective or relative matter? (2) The substance of morality: Are there certain actions that are absolutely forbidden, no matter what the consequences? When evaluating a person's action, in what way do his or her motives matter? And (3) the importance of morality: Should we really care whether we do the right thing? Along the way we will consider the contributions of major figures in moral philosophy, including Plato, David Hume, Immanuel Kant, Bernard Williams, Philippa Foot, and others.
name: Introduction to Moral Philosophy
title: WCAS PHIL 260-0-20 Introduction to Moral Philosophy

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will
(1) Gain an understanding of important issues and theories in moral philosophy.
(2) Learn to interpret and philosophical texts and arguments.
(3) Critically evaluate their own moral convictions.
(4) Learn to construct arguments and clearly explain philosophical ideas in writing.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation will be based on essays and a final exam.
